required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effect of a Predictive Model of Bowel Preparation Based on Procedure-related Factors
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of a Predictive Model of Bowel Preparation Based on Procedure-related Factors: a Multicenter, Randomized Controlled Study

lead_sponsor.agency: Air Force Military Medical University, China

clinical_study.source: Air Force Military Medical University, China

brief_summary.textblock:
The rate of adequate bowel preparation is one of important quality indicators of colonoscopy. Inadequate bowel preparation negatively affects the outcomes of colonoscopy. If patients with inadequate bowel preparation were identified before the procedure, enhanced strategy could be offered to achieve better bowel cleaning. Currently, there were three predicting models of inadequate bowel preparation established based on patient-related factors. So far, none of predictive models have been tested in other than their validation cohort populations, and no study has attempted to apply a different regimen to patients presenting with risk factors for inadequate colon cleanliness. In previous studies, we established a prediction model based on procedure-related factors, which has better accuracy and can better predict the quality of bowel preparation.
The aim of this study is to compare the quality of bowel preparation by using a predictive model based on procedure-related factors versus the criterion group in unsedation patients

secondary_outcome.description: The proportion of participants with at least one adenoma in each group

secondary_outcome.measure: Overall complication related to bowel preparation

arm_group.description: Colonoscopy was performed in the control group directly.

Patients with score ≥3 were asked to taking another dose of PEG (1.5L) within 1-2 hours. Colonoscopy was performed in afternoon (about 4h after drinking PEG). Patients with score<3 in IM group colonoscopy directly.

intervention.description: Before colonoscopy, patient-related and procedure-related parameters were collected by one investigator in each center. In MI group, a procedure-based score, used for predicting inadequate bowel preparation, was calculated for each patients. Patients with score ≥3 were asked to taking another dose of PEG (1.5L) within 1-2 hours. Colonoscopy was performed in afternoon (about 4h after drinking PEG). Patients with score<3 in IM group and those in the control group underwent colonoscopy directly

Predicting inadequate bowel preparation for colonoscopy in participants receiving split-dose bowel preparation: development and validation of a prediction score. Gastrointest Endosc. 2015 Mar;81(3):665-72. doi: 10.1016/j.gie.2014.09.066. Epub 2015 Jan 17.
